front.title: DoH/DoT Deployment Considerations for Home Networks

abstract.t: This document discusses DoT/DoH deployment considerations for home networks. It particularly sketches the required steps to use DoT/DoH provided by local networks.
One of the goals of the document is to assess to what extent existing tools can be used to provide such service. Extensions are proposed for identified gaps.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Internet Service Providers (ISPs) traditionally provide DNS resolvers to their customers. Typically, ISPs deploy the following mechanisms to advertise a list of DNS resolvers to their customers:

list.t: Protocol Configuration Options in cellular networks (TS.24008).

section.t: The communication between a customer's device (Customer Premise Equipment (CPE) or User Equipment (UE)) and an ISP-supplied DNS resolver takes then place using cleartext DNS messages (Do53, ). Some examples are depicted in . For the case of cellular networks, connectivity can be directly provided to a UE or to a CPE. Mechanisms used within the LAN are similar in both fixed and cellular CPE-based broadband service offerings.

ISPs use DNS to provide advanced services such as (non exhaustive) malware filtering, parental control, or VoD (Video on Demand) optimization. DNS is also a central component for mastering the quality of experience for current latency-sensitive services, but also emerging services (e.g., Ultra Reliability and Low Latency Communications (uRLLC) or Enhanced Mobile Broadband (eMBB)). For example, the latency targets set in the context of 5G are 1ms (uRLLC) and 4ms (eMBB). An ISP will be able to provide such services if deployed close to the user (e.g., by means of Edge Computing techniques and resources) and if the various involved communications legs are optimized (DNS, in particular). Relying upon local DNS resolvers will therefore contribute to meet the aforementioned service requirements. The use of external resolvers is likely to induce an extra service delay (e.g., 15 ms) which exceeds by far the service target (1 or 4 ms).

This document focuses on the support of DNS-over-HTTPS (DoH) or DNS-over-TLS (DoT) by local networks. In particular, the document describes how a local DoH/DoT can be discovered and used by connected hosts.

It is not the intent of this document to argue in favor or against the generalization of DoH/DoT. Likewise, it is not the intent of the document to evaluate the benifits/impacts of enabling DoH/DoT within some networks. Furthermore, it is not the intent of the document to discuss which information can be supplied to third-party resolvers (e.g., ECS) for the sake of proper delivery of some services nor how alternative technical options to DNS can be used to deliver the service that are currently "coupled" with the DNS service.

Some ISPs rely upon external resolvers (e.g., outsourced service or public resolvers); these ISPs provide their customers with the IP addresses of these resolvers (configured on CPEs, typically) using the mechanisms listed above. This document does not preclude such deployments. It is up to each ISP to decide which list of DNS resolvers to advertise to its serviced devices.

section.title: Sample Deployment Scenarios
section.t: ISPs are used to manage service-specific configuration using, e.g., TR-069. For example, these tools may be used to provision authentication domain name (ADN) (defined in ) to managed CPEs if DoH or DoT is supported by a local network similar to what is depicted in .

DNS clients may try to establish DoH and/or DoT sessions with discovered DNS servers to determine whether these servers support DoH and/or DoT (). Alternatively, a DNS client may discover whether the DNS server in the local network supports DoH or DoT by using the mechanism discussed in Section 6 of . If DoH is supported by the DNS server, the DNS client may query for the URI resource record type to use the https URI scheme (Section 3 of ).

The CPE relays the list of DoT/DoH servers it learns for the network using mechanisms (e.g., DHCP, RA). In such context, direct DoH/DoT sessions will be established between a host serviced by a CPE and an ISP-supplied DoT/DoH server (see the example depicted in for a DoH/DoT-capable host).

In many deployments, the CPE embeds a DNS forwarder. The CPE advertises itself as the default DNS server to the hosts it serves. The CPE relies upon DHCP or RA to advertise itself to internal hosts as the default DoT/DoH/Do53 server. The CPE forwards DNS requests received from internal hosts and which it can not handle locally to an upstream DoH/DoT/Do53 resolver. Such deployment is required for IPv4 service continuity (e.g., ) or for supporting advanced services within the home (e.g., malware filtering, parental control, Manufacturer Usage Description (MUD) to only allow intended communications to and from the IoT device). When the CPE behaves as a DNS forwarder, DNS communications can be decomposed into two legs: The one between an internal host and the CPE.
The second one between the CPE and an upstream DNS resolver.
An ISP that wants to offer DoH/DoT to its customers may enable DoH/DoT in both legs as shown in . Additional considerations related to this approach are discussed in .

section.title: Hosting DoH/DoT Forwarder on the CPE
section.t: The following mechanisms can be used in order to host DoH/DoT forwarder on the CPE:

list.t: If a CPE is co-located with security services (e.g., malware filtering, parental control, MUD), the ISP can assign a unique FQDN (e.g., cpe1.example.com) and a domain-validated public certificate to the DoH/DoT forwarder on the CPE. Alternatively, the ISP can assign a unique FQDN to the managed CPE. The DoT/DoH forwarder will act like a public DoT/DoH server but will only be accessible from within the home network. DNS queries received outside the home network must be rejected by the DoH/DoT forwarder. This behavior adheres to REQ#8 in , but must be applied for both IPv4 and IPv6.

'ACME IP Identifier Validation Extension' can be used to issue a public certificate for the public IP address of the DoH/DoT forwarder. This mechanism requires the certificate issuance and renewal management to be done on the CPE itself. The HTTP Challenge (http-01) or TLS with Application Level Protocol Negotiation (TLS ALPN) challenge (tls-alpn-01) are used to prove the IP address ownership during certificate issuance. The issued certificate will have public IP address in iPAddress subjectAltName extension.The disadvantages of this mechanism are: (1) the certificate needs to be re-issued every time the IPv6 prefix or the public IPv4 address changes and (2) the CPE needs to run an HTTP(S) server until the ACME server validates that the challenge has completed and issues the requested certificate.

section.title: DNS Reference Identifier Option
section.t: As reported in Section 1.7.2 of : "few certification authorities issue server certificates based on IP addresses, but preliminary evidence indicates that such certificates are a very small percentage (less than 1%) of issued certificates".

In order to allow for PKIX-based authentication between a DNS client and a DoH/DoT server while accommodating for the current best practices for issuing certificates, this document allows for configuring authentication domain name and an IP address to be presented as a reference identifier for DNS authentication purposes.

The DNS client establishes DoH/DoT session with the discovered DNS IP address(es) and uses the mechanism discussed in Section 8 of to authenticate the DNS server certificate using the authentication domain name conveyed in the DNS Reference Identifier.

section.t: The DHCPv6 DNS Reference Identifier option is used to configure an authentication domain name of the DoH/DoT server. The format of this option is shown in .

list.t: Option-length: Length of the authentication-domain-name field in octets.
authentication-domain-name: A fully qualified domain name of the DoH/DoT server. This field is formatted as specified in Section 10 of .

section.title: Format of DHCPv4 DNS Reference Identifier Option
section.t: The DHCPv4 DNS Reference Identifier option is used to configure a authentication domain name of the DoH/DoT server. The format of this option is illustrated in .

figure.title: DHCPv4 DNS Reference Identifier Option
figure.artwork:
Code Length Authentication domain name +-----+-----+-----+-----+-----+-----+-----+-- |TBA2 | n | s1 | s2 | s3 | s4 | s5 | ... +-----+-----+-----+-----+-----+-----+-----+--
The values s1, s2, s3, etc. represent the domain name labels in the domain name encoding.

section.t:
The fields of the option shown in are as follows: Code: OPTION_V4_DNS_RI (TBA2, see ).
Length: Includes the length of the "authentication domain name" field in octets.
Authentication domain name: The domain name of the DoH/DoT server. This field is formatted as specified in Section 10 of .

section.title: Format of RA DNS Reference Identifier Option
section.t: The IPv6 Router Advertisement (RA) DNS Reference Identifier option is used to configure a authentication domain name of the DoH/DoT server. The format of this option is illustrated in .

The fields of the option shown in are as follows: Type: 8-bit identifier of the DNS Reference Identifier Option as assigned by the IANA (TBA3, see ).
Length: 8-bit unsigned integer. The length of the option (including the Type and Length fields) is in units of 8 octets.
Reserved: This field is unused. It MUST be initialized to zero by the sender and MUST be ignored by the receiver.
Lifetime: 32-bit unsigned integer. The maximum time in seconds (relative to the time the packet is received) over which the authentication domain name MAY be used as a DNS Reference Identifier. The value of Lifetime SHOULD by default be at least 3 * MaxRtrAdvInterval, where MaxRtrAdvInterval is the maximum RA interval as defined in . A value of all one bits (0xffffffff) represents infinity. A value of zero means that the DNS Reference Identifier MUST no longer be used.
Authentication domain name: The domain name of the DoH/DoT server. This field is formatted as specified in Section 10 of .

section.title: Locating DoH/DoT Servers
section.t: As mentioned in , a CPE or a host relies upon discovery mechanisms (such as PCO, DHCP, or RA) to retrieve DoH and DoT servers hosted by local networks. In the various scenarios sketched in , Do53, DoH, and DoT may terminate on the same IP address (or distinct IP addresses as depicted in ). Terminating Do53/DoH/DoT on the same or distinct IP addresses is deployment-specific.

From an IP reachability standpoint, DoH/DoT servers should be located by their address literals rather than their names. This avoids adding a dependency on another server to resolve the DoH/DoT name. Concretely, existing discovery mechanisms can be leveraged to learn the IP addresses of DoT/DoH servers while an authentication domain name is supplied by one of the means discussed in .

list.t: Note: It is unlikely that DoH and DoT will be offered simultaneously, but we need to indicate which one wins if DoH and DoT are supported.

section.t:
Additional considerations are discussed below for the use of DoH and DoT servers provided by local networks: If the DNS server IP address discovered using DHCP/RA is pre-configured in the OS or browser as a trusted resolver, the DNS client auto-upgrades to use the discovered DoH/DoT server.
If the DNS reference identity () is provided by means of DHCP/RA, the DNS client matches the domain name in the DNS Reference Identifier DHCP/RA option with the 'DNS-ID' identifier type within subjectAltName entry in the server certificate conveyed in the TLS handshake.
If the DNS reference identity is provided by means of DHCP/RA and the DNS client uses these IP addresses as a reference identity, the DNS client matches the IP address in the DNS DHCP/RA option with the 'iPAddress' stored in the subjectAltName entry in the server certificate conveyed in the TLS handshake.
Additional options are discussed below:

list.t: The Wi-Fi Alliance has released the Device Provisioning Protocol (DPP). If DPP is used, the configurator can securely configure devices in the home network with the local DoT/DoH server using DPP.

If a CPE is co-located with security services within the home network, the CPE can use WPA-PSK but with unique pre-shared keys for different endpoints to deal with security issues. In such networks, may be used to securely bootstrap endpoint devices with the authentication domain name (ADN) and DNS server certificate of the local network's DoH/DoT server. The OS would not know if the WPA pre-shared-key is the same for all clients or a unique pre-shared key is assigned to the host. Hence, the user has to indicate to the system that a unique pre-shared key is assigned to trigger the bootstrapping procedure. If the device joins a home network using a single shared password among all the attached devices, a compromised device can host a fake access point, and the device cannot be securely bootstrapped with the home network's DoH/DoT server.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: An attacker can get a domain name, doman-validated public certificate from a CA, host a DoT/DoH server and claim the best DNS privacy preservation policy. Also, an attacker within the home network can use the public IP address, get an 'IP address'-validated public certificate from a CA, host a DoT/DoH server and claim the best DNS privacy preservation policy.

Because DHCP/RA messages are not encrypted or protected against modification in any way, their content can be spoofed or modified by compromised devices within the home network. An attacker can spoof the DHCP/RA response to provide the attacker's DoT/DoH server. Note that such an attacker can mount other attacks as discussed in Section 22 of . Furthermore, if the browser or the OS is pre-configured with a list of DNS servers where some perform malware filtering and others do not, an attacker can prevent contacting the preferred filtering DNS servers causing a downgrade attack to a non-filtering DNS server, which the attacker can leverage to deliver malware.

The use of DoH/DoT also depends on the user's policies. For example, the user may indicate his/her consent to use (or not) the locally-discovered DoH/DoT server. The DNS client must adhere to these policies.
DoH/DoT servers discovered using insecure discovery mechanisms like DHCP/RA are used by a DNS client if the insecurely discovered DoH/DoT server is pre-configured in the OS or the browser.

DoH/DoT servers discovered using insecure discovery mechanisms like DHCP/RA are used by a DNS client if the insecurely discovered DoH/DoT server is pre-configured in the OS or the browser, offers malware filtering service and meets the privacy preserving data policy requirements of the user.

If the insecurely discovered DoH/DoT server is not pre-configured in the OS or browser, its policy information must be cryptographically attested by the ISP (e.g., ); user consent is required to use the locally-discovered DoH/DoT server.

DOT/DoH sessions with rogue servers spoofing the IP address of a DNS server will fail because the DNS client will fail to authenticate that rogue server because of PKIX authentication based on the authentication domain name in the Reference Identifier Option. DNS clients that ignore authentication failures and accept spoofed certificate will be subject to attacks (e.g., redirect to malicious servers, intercept sensitive data).

section.title: Distinct
section.t: In deployment where DoH/DoT/Do53 are not co-located, the ISP may return a list of servers that is composed of DoH (and/or DoT) and Do53 servers in addition to the DNS Reference Identifier Option (). A host that is also DoH-capable (and/or DoT-capable), will try to establish a DoH (and/or DoT) session to that list. DoT and/or DoH are supported if the client succeeds to establish a session. Let's consider that the DoH server is reachable at 2001:db8:122:300::2 (S2 in ) while the Do53 server is reachable at 2001:db8:122:300::1 (S1 in ). The DHCP server will then return a list that includes both 2001:db8:122:300::1 and 2001:db8:122:300::2 to a requesting DNS client. That list is passed to the DNS client. A legacy Do53 client will select 2001:db8:122:300::1 (S1) while a DoH client will select 2001:db8:122:300::2 (S2).
